Title: Prove a $\pi$ inequality: $\left(1+\frac1\pi\right)^{\pi+1}<\pi$
Content:
Prove $$\left(1+\frac{1}{\pi}\right)^{\pi+1}<\pi$$ 
  without using calculator I have tried to show that the derivative of $f(x)=x-\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right)^{x+1}$ is greater than zero , at $x=\pi$ but, it is too hard for me.
AcceptedAnswer: $$g(x)=\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right)^{x+1}$$ is a decreasing function over $\mathbb{R}^+$ in virtue of the Bernoulli inequality. Since $\frac{22}{7}>\pi$ (the Archimedean approximation), it is sufficient to show that $g(22/7)<\pi$. Since $\left(1+\frac{7}{22}\right)^{29} < 3015$, it is sufficient to show that $\pi^7>3015$. This follows from $\pi>3.141$.
